Tejal,

 

I deal with a lot of legacy JSP pages that are full of program (access
rights, business, etc.) logic, very long, and none of them are Unit
tested.  Those pages are very hard to maintain and to refactor.

 

My experience is that it is always best to have JSP concentrated on
displaying data, nothing more.  That includes of course handling more or
less data structures.  But that should be it.  If there is programming
logic that should go into a handler class or a helper class.  With that
design approach you are now on easier to test Java classes.  Now you can
use Mock Objects for testing those classes if they are for example
Servlets as handlers.  I think it is always best to move all programming
logic that is not concerned about presentation in as much as possible
POJOs which are always much easier to test.

 

From your previous posting I know that you are experimenting with
Cactus.  I never liked that approach because it makes my tests dependent
on a Servlet engine.

 

If you follow my depicted approach and still see the urge to test what
is left in the JSPs, than use some testing framework like Selenium
(http://openqa.org/selenium/)

 

Andreas
